criteria: Application of the Remainder Theorem to find Factors
descriptions: Does not demonstrate understanding of the Remainder Theorem. Unable to relate p(a) to the remainder of polynomial division.
Shows limited understanding of the Remainder Theorem. Struggles to connect p(a) with the remainder when dividing by x - a.
Demonstrates a basic understanding of the Remainder Theorem. Can sometimes relate p(a) to the remainder, but with inconsistencies.
Understands the Remainder Theorem and can relate p(a) to the remainder when dividing by x - a in simple cases.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of the Remainder Theorem. Can accurately relate p(a) to the remainder and apply it to various polynomials.
Exhibits a comprehensive understanding of the Remainder Theorem. Can fluently relate p(a) to the remainder, apply it to complex polynomials, and explain the underlying concepts.
Unable to apply the Remainder Theorem to determine if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).
Struggles to apply the Remainder Theorem to find factors, making frequent errors.
Can apply the Remainder Theorem to find factors in simple cases but struggles with more complex polynomials.
Applies the Remainder Theorem to find factors of polynomials with some accuracy.
Effectively uses the Remainder Theorem to find factors of various polynomials.
Masterfully uses the Remainder Theorem to efficiently find factors of complex polynomials and justifies their reasoning clearly.
Does not recognize the relationship between zeros of a polynomial and its factors.
Shows a weak understanding of the connection between zeros and factors.
Recognizes the connection between zeros and factors in simple cases, but not consistently.
Understands that if p(a) = 0, then (x - a) is a factor, and vice versa.
Clearly articulates the relationship between zeros and factors and uses it effectively in problem-solving.
Provides a nuanced explanation of the deep relationship between zeros and factors and applies this understanding to solve challenging problems.
